title: God's Redemption and Assurance
shortSummary: Isaiah 43 reveals God's sovereign power as the Redeemer of Israel, assuring His people of His presence and protection through trials. The chapter emphasizes God's unique role as Savior and Creator, calling Israel to trust Him and proclaim His glory. It also highlights the promise of new things God will do, inviting His people to remember His faithfulness and repent from their sins.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - During the Assyrian and Babylonian threats to Israel and Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jacob
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch representing the nation of Israel, addressed by God as His chosen and redeemed people.

keyCharacters.name: Israel
keyCharacters.description: The collective people of God descended from Jacob, called to trust in God's salvation and restoration.

keyCharacters.name: Babylon
keyCharacters.description: The foreign power used by God as an instrument of judgment against Israel's enemies.

keyCharacters.name: Chaldeans
keyCharacters.description: A people allied with Babylon, mentioned as part of God's judgment on Israel's oppressors.

definitions.definition: To be bought back or delivered from bondage or sin by a price paid, signifying God's saving action on behalf of His people.
A title for God emphasizing His purity, separateness, and covenant relationship with Israel.
A price paid to free someone from captivity or bondage, here symbolizing God's deliverance of Israel.
To treat something sacred with disrespect or irreverence, indicating judgment against those who defile God's sanctuary.
Those who testify to the truth of God's identity and actions, called here to affirm God's uniqueness and sovereignty.

outline.heading: God’s Assurance of Redemption and Presence
outline.description: God reassures Israel of His redemption, calling them by name and promising His presence through all dangers. He declares His love and the gathering of His people from all directions for His glory.

outline.heading: God’s Unique Sovereignty and Witness
outline.description: God challenges the nations to prove their gods’ power, affirming that He alone is God, Savior, and Creator. Israel is called to be His witnesses, recognizing His eternal existence and unmatched authority.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment on Babylon and Deliverance
outline.description: God declares His role as Redeemer through the judgment of Babylon and the defeat of their armies, demonstrating His power to save His people.

outline.heading: The Promise of New Things and Provision
outline.description: God calls His people to forget past troubles and look forward to the new things He will do, including making a way in the wilderness and providing water in the desert for His chosen.

outline.heading: Israel’s Unfaithfulness and God’s Forgiveness
outline.description: God confronts Israel’s failure to honor Him with sacrifices and calls them to repentance, yet He promises to blot out their transgressions for His own sake.

application: Trust in God’s presence and protection during life’s trials, remembering He has redeemed you and calls you by name.
Confess and repent from sin, knowing that God is faithful to forgive and restore those who turn to Him.
Be a witness to God’s unique sovereignty and salvation by living a life that proclaims His glory to others.
Look forward with hope to the new things God will do, even when past circumstances seem discouraging.

keyVerses.text: But now thus saith the LORD that created thee, O Jacob, and he that formed thee, O Israel, Fear not: for I have redeemed thee, I have called thee by thy name; thou art mine.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes God’s personal relationship with His people, assuring them of redemption and ownership.

keyVerses.text: Ye are my witnesses, saith the LORD, and my servant whom I have chosen: that ye may know and believe me, and understand that I am he: before me there was no God formed, neither shall there be after me.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights Israel’s role as God’s chosen witnesses, affirming His uniqueness as the one true God.

keyVerses.text: Remember ye not the former things, neither consider the things of old. Behold, I will do a new thing; now it shall spring forth; shall ye not know it? I will even make a way in the wilderness, and rivers in the desert.
keyVerses.significance: These verses encourage believers to trust God’s power to bring renewal and provision in seemingly impossible situations.

keyVerses.text: I, even I, am he that blotteth out thy transgressions for mine own sake, and will not remember thy sins.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers of God’s gracious forgiveness, emphasizing His initiative in cleansing sin.
